awd_titl_txt: Superfluid and Crust Dynamics of Neutron Stars and the Observable Consequences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a theoretical project to model neutron star structure and to explore the consequences for observations of such objects.  Neutron stars are the dead remnants of moderately massive stars, and have extremely high densities.  The main goal of the work is to develop realistic models of the rotational and crust dynamics of neutron stars, and to explore (1) the observable effects of superfluid turbulence, (2) the coupling of the crust to the interior of the neutron star, and (3) how the deep crust responds to shear stresses.

Dr. Link will also continue his longstanding efforts to enhance in teaching and training, improve infrastructure for education and research, and undertake outreach and engagement activities with the local community.  The project is also expected to have an impact in the theoretical understanding of matter at high density and of nuclear interactions in conditions not achievable in terrestrial laboratories.

por.por_cntn:
Neutron stars are dense and exotic stellar remnants born in supernova explosions. With over a solar mass of matter compressed into an object only 20 km across, neutron stars contain by far the densest matter known. At the high densities reached inside a neutron star, the matter dissolves into a neutron-rich liquid with interesting consequences for the star's evolution. In particular, neutron stars exhibit a variety of spin irregularities, such as sudden spin glitches and stochastic variations in spin rate. Spin glitches are attributed to variable coupling between the neutron star crust and the liquid interior. How this coupling is suddenly triggered has been a long-standing question, and one intriguing proposal is that the liquid interior make transitions into and out of turbulent states, with spin glitches representing these transitions. 

With the aim of understanding observed spin glitches and other spin irregularities in neutron stars, we studied the stability of the liquid interior of a neutron star. We find that the stellar interior is stabilized by the strong magnetic field that a neutron star possesses. Turbulence cannot occur under most conditions, and so turbulent transitions cannot be the explanation of spin glitches. An exceptional case is that of a wobbling neutron star. If neutron star can somehow be set to wobble (which might not be possible), the stellar interior can become turbulent, likely driving interesting rotational dynamics. Our results will inform future theoretical models of spin irregularities in neutron stars. This work has broader impact on our understanding of the spin evolution of neutron stars, and how the evolution is affected by magnetic fields.

Magnetars are the most strongly magnetized neutron stars, with magnetic fields a factor of 1,000 larger than the average in the neutron star population, and a factor of 10 billion larger than the strongest magnetic fields that can be only briefly produced in terrestrial laboratories. In a magnetar, the strong magnetic field decays over millennia, driving powerful gamma-ray flares. Oscillations have been observed to accompany flares, which are interpreted as stellar oscillations. Interesting questions surround the origin of these oscillations: What determines the oscillation frequencies? How are the oscillations excited?

 The strong magnetic field of a magnetar is predicted to be highly tangled. We have shown that the tangled field makes the star effectively rigid, so that it will oscillate at frequencies of typically 100 Hz, as observed. We studied in detail how these oscillations could be excited. In comparison with observations, we constrained the deposition geometry of the flare energy. The energy cannot be deposited too deep in the star, or it will not exit the star as quickly as observed. Nor can the energy be deposited entirely outside the star, or stellar oscillations cannot be excited to observable amplitudes. Our results will inform future modeling of the energy deposition process. Our work has broader impact on the relationship of very strong magnetic fields to observed explosive phenomena in magnetars.
